titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Carroll L. V. Meeks Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 07:23

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The major portion of the papers consists of research materials for a study of the architecture of Yale University; research materials on Connecticut architecture, railroad stations, and Works Progress Administration files for Connecticut; and research for Carroll Meeks's book on Italian architecture, published in 1966. Included in the materials on Yale are photographs, articles, manuscripts, notes and bibliographies. Additional papers reflect Meeks's teaching career at Yale University (1930-1966) and his membership in organizations dedicated to architectural preservation. His correspondence includes letters from a number of notable art historians. Prominent among the correspondents are James Ackerman, Turpin C. Bannister, Kingman Brewster, James Marston Fitch, Siegfried Giedion, Maynard Mack, Denis Mack Smith, Lewis Mumford, Richard Neutra, Robert Rosenblum, Paul Rudolph, Vincent Scully, Sir John N. Summerson, Christopher Tunnard, and Rudolf Wittkower.

origination.label: creator
origination.persname: Meeks, Carroll L. V. (Carroll Louis Vanderslice), 1907-1966

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Box 33, student evaluations, is restricted as established by Yale Corporation regulations.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Carroll L. V. Meeks Papers (MS 706). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection has been inventoried as received, and includes two accessions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Carroll L. V. Meeks Papers consist of eighteen linear feet of correspondence, research material, photographs, and miscellaneous papers relating to Meeks's career as a Yale professor and historian of architecture. They have been minimally processed and are roughly organized by subject as received from the donor. The following is an outline of the materials: Papers related to Yale buildings and grounds (boxes 1-4); Additional papers related to Yale architecture and to Italian architecture, but less organized (boxes 5-16); Card files containing notes on Italian architecture (boxes 17-26); Mounted photographs of Street Hall, Yale University (box 27, which has been transferred to the Yale Picture Collection); Files containing professional correspondence and miscellaneous papers arranged alphabetically by subject or correspondent (boxes 28-32); Papers related to evaluation of students' work (box 33, which is closed to researchers); Printed articles, primarily in Italian, on art and architecture (box 34, a folio)
Meeks's research material on the architecture of railroad stations, which was in the Slides and Photograph Collection, was transferred to Manuscripts and Archives, SML, in 1991.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Carroll Louis Vanderslice Meeks was born in Bridgeport, Connecticut on May 21, 1907. He received his Ph.B. degree from Yale University in 1928, his B.F.A. in 1931, and his M.A. in 1934. Meeks earned a Ph.D. from Harvard in 1948. He was a member of the Yale faculty from 1930 until his death on August 27, 1966.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This box is closed to research because of university policy on access to student records.

did.unittitle: Printed articles, primarily in Italian, on art and architecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Received from: Transferred from the Slides and Photographs Collection, Street Hall, 1991 Feb

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This is a file, arranged alphabetically by town name, of student papers on individual buildings throughout Connecticut. Most of the buildings seem to be single family houses, but there are also churches, town halls, taverns, and inns. The period emphasized is colonial, although there are a few 19th century buildings as well. All buildings were standing at the time the papers were written.

did.unittitle: Historic American Building Survey (HABS): photographs, supplement list, copy book list

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This is the New Haven section of the Connecticut architecture file but far more extensive in plan. It was compiled as a working file for a projected architectural history of New Haven. The guide was never published in this form, but it was later reworked and published as New Haven: a Guide to Architecture and Urban Design, by Elizabeth Mills Brown in 1976.
Particularly important in this material are photographs of the now destroyed City Hall annex and of the interior of the Davies mansion on Prospect Hill.
The preliminary texts and photographs are grouped in folders roughly by area of New Haven.

did.unittitle: Historic American Building Survey for New Haven, Fairfield, Litchfield, and Middlesex counties,

Working papers from a Yale seminar of George Hersey co-taught with Elizabeth Mills Brown, related to New Haven guide
Jonathan Riley House, Rocky Hill: plans, photographs
Plans of the Branford Room, Yale University Art Gallery, by Harvey Bartholomew Mitsui
Photographs of buildings on Orchard and Dickerman Streets

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This file is arranged alphabetically by town or city name. It is worldwide, and includes plans, photographs, and material collected as research material for Professor Meeks' book, The Railroad Station, New Haven, Yale University Press, 1956. The published book is still the best guide to this file. There are many things in the file, however, which are not in the book.

did.unittitle: Index of U.S. railroad stations listed chronologically from 1830-1890
Index of town or city name
Bismarck, North Dakota - Garwood Depot, Eagle Lake, Texas

odd.head: General note
odd.p: These files contain architectural surveys of old buildings in Connecticut. The data sheets and photographs were compiled by the WPA project in 1935-1936, preliminary to the publication of a Connecticut guide written by that project. The files are arranged alphabetically by town.
